posts.name: sigfun
posts.cooked:
How does the Signal team take into consideration the suggested features in the forum and how are they planned in the roadmap?

It would be interesting to know what features have been considered and accepted, which ones are under consideration, which ones are under consideration but are infeasible given Signal constraints on privacy or team/budget size, which ones have been rejected because it doesn‚Äôt align with Signal (with reason included), etc.
I know that making the roadmap public for certain features would be negative, for example if it is a novel feature that you want to have an edge in time to market or something the team is proud and wants to surprise its user base, but for all other features could we have at least insights into what‚Äôs planned?
I have many bookmarked features that have been in discussion only by the Signal users on and off for years and that make using Signal more annoying / joyful than it should be, and I say that being a Signal user before it was even Signal.

By knowing what‚Äôs the triage status of these features by the Signal team at least one could know what‚Äôs in store for us. Signal is at the end of the day a niche app with a passionate user base who takes privacy seriously, the majority of other user bases use other apps because of convenience or inertia/network effect, not because of a rational choice. Therefore giving your user base insights into this would help understand the future of an app where they are invested.
The Signal team does not publish a public roadmap. The best we get is from following the commit logs of the respective projects (iOS, Android, Desktop, Server).

link_counts.title: A forum category is a mediocre way to track feature requests

posts.name: sigfun
posts.cooked:
You are right, unfortunately, but that‚Äôs the purpose of this conversation. My wish is to know which features will be done or won‚Äôt be done (and ideally why not) to form an idea of the future of the app and the rate of change it‚Äôll have.

I‚Äôve noticed that after years of using Signal is still hard (but easier than before) to convince people to start using it or even keep using it because there isn‚Äôt enough network effect and/or is missing features. The network effect gets worsened if there aren‚Äôt enough features to maintain and attract new users. So basically having desirable features is a key component.
I don‚Äôt know the plans with Signal but if it is to reach more people, then having desirable features - as long as they align with the mission of ‚Äúenable secure global communication through open source privacy technology‚Äù - is a must. Otherwise that ‚Äúglobal communication‚Äù is just ‚Äúniche groups communication‚Äù; can‚Äôt be global if you don‚Äôt cater a global audience. But again, I don‚Äôt know if that is the objective.

Knowing which features have been assessed at least allows me to evaluate the level of invest and effort in the long term with Signal and being able to say to people I am telling about Signal: ‚ÄúHey John, this feature you want isn‚Äôt there yet, but there are plans to add it in 3 months, top‚Äù.

Not having a public roadmap allows the Signal team to continuously reevaluate the features they want to develop and ship. They don‚Äôt have to commit to a feature until it‚Äôs almost ready for release and allows them to drop features that aren‚Äôt up to their standard of quality, security, and privacy anywhere along the development process.

If they were to have a public roadmap, it would create false expectations by users of Signal for features that may never come; degrading the public opinion of Signal and adding a bad incentive for the organization.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
sigfun:

How does the Signal team take into consideration the suggested features in the forum

They obviously look at them because many requests have been implemented.

sigfun:

and how are they planned in the roadmap?

Nobody knows except Signal. They don‚Äôt have hard release dates nor share roadmaps for feature releases.

Signal has limited capital and small developer teams. They generally don‚Äôt release incomplete features and patch later like most software companies do because they simply can‚Äôt afford the same staff bloat that happens elsewhere.

The recent blog post lays out where the money goes.

Edit: Signal‚Äôs CTO was on a podcast in March and was pretty insightful.

link_counts.title: Signal >> Blog >> Privacy is Priceless, but Signal is Expensive

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: Sorry to bump this old thread, but I‚Äôm wondering if there is now a roadmap anywhere. I heard some people mention some upcoming features like cloud backups, scheduled sending, etc. but I can‚Äôt seem to find where this information is coming from. Is there a public roadmap now?

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
There‚Äôs no roadmap.

You can see extensive work on cloud backups in Encrypted cloud backups over the last ~ year.

Scheduled sending has been around for awhile on Android.

Watching the beta threads and GitHub is the closest there is to a roadmap.

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: Ah, I understand now. That sounds like a lot of work to look through commits to see how close a feature is to being implemented, but if it‚Äôs the best we have then that makes sense. Thanks for the info.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
You don‚Äôt have to look through commits. You can just look at the first post in any beta thread to see what‚Äôs incoming imminently.

For example:

Android - Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 7.13 release

iOS - Beta feedback for the upcoming iOS 7.23 release

Desktop - Beta feedback for the upcoming Desktop 7.19 release

link_counts.title: Beta feedback for the upcoming iOS 7.23 release
Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 7.13 release
Beta feedback for the upcoming Desktop 7.19 release

posts.cooked:
Avitus:

You don‚Äôt have to look through commits. You can just look at the first post in any beta thread to see what‚Äôs incoming imminently.

You can do so but that actually seldom shows what they are developing in the background.
You may see the most important changes that are visible for all users, but you won‚Äôt really see anything else.
Therefore you have to read through the comments.

Example:

Beta feedback for the upcoming iOS 7.23 release

Release notes:

  • Your microphone will automatically switch to being muted whenever you join a large group call, so now nobody will hear you say ‚Äúomg there are so many people in here‚Äù unless you unmute first.

Here, you see the release notes, but nothing else.

Beta feedback for the upcoming iOS 7.21 release

Add support for profile change chat updates to Backups [37]

You can indeed see some interesting details in the comments.

link_counts.title: Beta feedback for the upcoming iOS 7.21 release
Beta feedback for the upcoming iOS 7.23 release

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Lkunited:

You may see the most important changes that are visible for all users

This is what 99.9% of users of any software care about.

Avitus:

This is what 99.9% of users of any software care about.

Of course it is but as I understood @pickle_umbrella that isn‚Äôt what he wants:
He requested to know about the acceptance of feature requests and the development in general,
and the release notes just show this one week before the update gets released so he won‚Äôt be able to know what is currently developed more than one week in the future.

Edit:
Maybe we shouldn‚Äôt count him to the 99.9% of the users

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: Yeah, I have a fair amount of suggestions and feedback since I use Signal on a daily basis. It would be nice to know if the devs are planning to work on features or improvements I request. Also, it would prevent me from suggesting something that is already planned and creating unnecessary posts on here.

Not having a public roadmap allows the Signal team to continuously reevaluate the features they want to develop and ship. @bjoel So, basically you state that committing to a goal (devilering one or more desired features), while being open and transparant on it in the progress to achieve these goals, is not a good thing?

With all respect, I can‚Äôt see why commitment, openness and transparancy in developing to (much desired) features, isn‚Äôt a good thing.

posts.edit_reason: 2 posts were merged in by Herohtar

posts.cooked: Agree entirely. For an open-source app that operates under a not-for-profit umbrella - greater transparency seems like a good goal. There are other FOSS projects who do this.

posts.name: sigfun
posts.cooked:
Related to this, and I think it‚Äôs the most immediate problem of all, is that one reports an issue and usually gets back a ‚ÄúTracking.‚Äù. Ok, fine, but how do I know if I need to report it again on every beta or not? Is it going to be worked on or not? Is it being worked already so no need to report twice or maybe it got lost between the cracks?

It complicates collaborating with the Signal team (plus really on demotivates reporting issues).

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: you can usually see in the commits if a fix was implemented. and if it‚Äôs not clear enough a staff member will usually just tell you that they attempted a fix.

image987√ó249 32.9 KB

Link to post here

(couldn‚Äôt figure out how to quote in a different thread)

@scott-signal Does this also imply that there is no list of features that will ever be published? I do not mind if a timeline isn‚Äôt there, but not even having a list of features that are being prioritized is so bad. I polite beg that this policy be changes to at the very least, tell what is being prioritized.

I (and many) will be extremely happy with just

We are working on

  1. Feature A
  2. Feature B

We have a policy of no eta so they release when they release

Or even

The next feature we‚Äôre focusing on is [so and so].

We have a policy of no eta so they release when they release

That‚Äôs all many ask for. That is all. SOMETHING, kind people. Please.

Why would that be relevant to users you ask? Because if I am interested in the feature, I‚Äôll donate more. I get my friends to donate more. I‚Äôll get my friends and I to do company matching.

Again, looking at commits IS NOT user-friendly or something that‚Äôs accessible to the broad userbase. Unless signal aims to cater to only tech-proficient users who can look and parse and follow commits and git history.

It‚Äôll also play nicely into marketing efforts.

link_counts.title: Collapsible Sidebar (hide left contact drawer to show only avatars)

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
nullptr:

We are working on

  1. Feature A
  2. Feature B

We have a policy of no eta so they release when they release

that‚Äôs essentially what the commit history is. take a look at Stories / Status Updates Hide phone number (phone number privacy) or even the recent Encrypted cloud backups and you‚Äôll see people put the relevant commits. Key Transparency is coming to Signal? was found by looking at the commit history.
the reason to do it that way is that if a feature is abandoned for a while or delayed, it‚Äôs not going back on any promise. Usernames took years to implement. had they done a roadmap of any kind, it would have been there since 2019.

link_counts.title: Key Transparency is coming to Signal?

posts.cooked:
Again, looking at commits IS NOT user-friendly or something that‚Äôs accessible to the broad userbase. Unless signal aims to cater to only tech-proficient users who can look and parse and follow commits and git history.

rassilon1963:

commit history

I don‚Äôt know know what to say. Every other OSS project funded by the users has a public roadmap.

it would have been there since 2019

Yes and it got traction again because whatsapp added it and there was immediate pressure to add it again. Which is fine, but goes to show priorities aren‚Äôt really based off of user requests.

I am legitimately confused as to why reasonable requests and points by users are dismissed, trivialized, removed, locked and blocked by the same old points, by what seems to me like the same Top contributors, each and every single time. See feature requests like history transfer as an opt-in for newly linked devices, and many others.

By that I don‚Äôt mean you need to celebrate and say ‚Äúyeah your points are excellent‚Äù and always be supportive, I just mean that essentially saying ‚Äúwell we don‚Äôt have but there is this other that you can use (implying we don‚Äôt really need it)‚Äù.

I can only read not having a roadmap and asking users to see commits and fish out what‚Äôs happening as catering only to the tech-literate and intentionally not being transparent to the userbase.

I‚Äôll stop wasting my breath asking for something that Signal has zero intentions of considering. Honestly. I am tired. I did my part as ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù and ‚Äúuser‚Äù in showing my support for it.
